metadata.title: Hawker 800
aws::graph::propositions: Military Variants of the Hawker 800 Aircraft
Japan Air Self-Defense Force uses a maritime search and rescue variant of the Hawker 800.
The maritime search and rescue variant of the Hawker 800 is designated U-125A in Japan Air Self-Defense Force service.
Japan was using the U-125A variant as of 2008.
The U-125A has large observation windows.
The U-125A has a flare dispenser system.
The U-125A has a marker-buoy dispenser system.
The U-125A has a life-raft dropping system.
The U-125A has an emergency equipment dropping system.
The U-125A has enhanced salt water corrosion prevention.
The U-125A is equipped with a Toshiba 360-degree search radar.
The U-125A is equipped with Melco thermal imaging equipment.
The U-125A is equipped with military communications equipment for its mission.
South Korea uses a military version of the Hawker 800XP.
South Korea was using the military version of the Hawker 800XP as of 2008.
South Korea uses the Hawker 800XP for tactical aerial reconnaissance.
South Korea uses the Hawker 800XP for surveillance tasks.
South Korea uses the Hawker 800XP for SIGINT (SIGnals INTelligence) tasks.
Eight specially equipped Hawker 800XP aircraft were delivered to South Korea in 2000.
The Republic of Korea Air Force calls their Hawker 800XP aircraft RC-800s.
The RC-800s are based at Seoul Air Base.

The Republic of Korea Air Force calls their Hawker 800XP aircraft RC-800s.
The RC-800s are based at Seoul Air Base.

text:
### Military variants

Japan uses (as of 2008) a maritime search and rescue variant of the Hawker 800. It is designated U-125A in Japan Air Self-Defense Force service. This variant has large observation windows, a flare and marker-buoy dispenser system, a life-raft and emergency equipment dropping system, and enhanced salt water corrosion prevention. The aircraft also has a Toshiba 360-degree search radar, Melco thermal imaging equipment, and other military communications equipment for its mission.
A military version of the Hawker 800XP is (as of 2008) in use by South Korea for tactical aerial reconnaissance, surveillance and SIGINT (SIGnals INTelligence) tasks, and 8 specially equipped aircraft were delivered in 2000. The Republic of Korea Air Force calls them RC-800s, and they are based at Seoul Air Base.
